descriptionSet.description: An Indian woman can be seen, wearing a sari and drinking tea. She is wearing flowers in her hair, bangles on her hands and has a big bindi (the dot on her forehead). Her earrings, and jewellery suggest that she is a traditional married Indian woman.

location.name: Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art
Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art

rights.text: Copyrighted. Copyright with the original artists and publishers.

titleSet.title: Poster of a woman drinking tea

hra:item.hra:value: Plavi
text-en: Plavi

description-en: An Indian woman can be seen, wearing a sari and drinking tea. She is wearing flowers in her hair, bangles on her hands and has a big bindi (the dot on her forehead). Her earrings, and jewellery suggest that she is a traditional married Indian woman. (sp)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: The process by which tea came to be cultivated on the subcontinent and consumed by upper-class Indians as a social beverage has been fairly well documented â€” e.g., in historian Gautam Bhadra's pioneering catalogue essay for an exhibition of tea advertising held in Calcutta in 2005, and in Arup Kumar Dutta's celebratory 1992 volume, underwritten by the Assam Tea Corporation, Ltd. (Philip Lutgendorf)(gs)
related literature: Bhadra, Gautam 2005. "From an Imperial Product to a National Drink". Calcutta: CSSSC. (gs)
related literature: Chatterjee, Piya. 2001. "A Time for Tea." Durham, NC: Duke University Press. (gs)
related literature: Collingham, Elizabeth M. 2006. "Curry, a tale of cooks and conquerors." New York: Oxford University Press. (gs)
related literature: de Certeau, Michel 1984. "The Practices of Everyday Life" . Berkeley: University of California Press. (gs)
related literature: Dutta, Arup Kumar. 1992. "Cha Garam, the tea story." Assam: Paloma Publications. (gs)

related literature: Lutgendorf, Philip 2010. Chai Why? The Triumph of Tea in India as Documented in the Priya Paul Collection http://www.tasveergharindia.net/cmsdesk/essay/89/index.html (18.4.2011)(gs)
related literature: Mair, Victor, and Erling Hoh. 2009. "The True History of Tea." London: Thames & Hudson. (gs)
related literature: Mintz, Sidney. 1985. "Sweetness and Power, the place of sugar in modern history". New York: Viking. (gs)
related literature: Storey, John 1999. "Cultural Consumption and Everyday Life". New York: Oxford University Press. (gs)
